REPORT OF AUDITOR OP PUBLIC ACCOUNTS : . STATE OF NEBRASKA Office of Auditor of Public Accounts • Honorable R. L. Cochran, Governor and • '...-,. Members of the Session of the .-.'■■ Nebraska Unicameral Legislature . ..'..' Lincoln, Nebraska Dear Governor and Members: In accordance with the laws of the State of Nebraska, Chapter 84-303, Comp. Statutes-Nebr. 1929, I take pleasure in submitting herewith my biennial report covering the state government's business transactions for the two years from July 1, 1936 to June 30, 1938. This report is made up of numerous statements and supporting sched - ules, which are listed under a table of contents, Page 10. The resources of the State of Nebraska on June 30, 1938 amounted to $74,483,917.35, or an increase in assets of $196,203.52 over June 30, 1936. This increase is made up as follows: Decrease: Cash on Hand $1,952,981.05 Cash due from County Treasurers 85,625.94 Increase: Accounts Receivable — Income Hospitals 215,584.95 Land, Buildings and Equipment 1,027,495.80 Bonds of Stats Trust Funds 166,376.28 Delinquent Taxes 825,353.48 Net Increase 196,203.52 Statement No. 1 reflects the resources of the State as of June 30, 1938. All outstanding unpaid warrants as of June 30, 1938, have been deducted from the cash balance as of the same date. The state of Nebraska has no bonded indebtedness. Your attention is directed to the condition of the state's treasury as shown in Schedule 1A. The cash on hand in the state treasury, on June 30, 1938, totaled $4,933,461.12, as compared with the cash bal - ance on June 30, 1936 of $6,886,442.17. These figures indicate a de - crease in the cash balance, with the prior two years, of approximately $1,952,981.05. This decrease can be accounted for by the fact that - ■

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS tax collections have fallen off, due to the adverse economic and drought conditions in the state. From the state, tax levy made in 1936, there was delinquent on June 30, 1938, 11.67 per cent, of the total amount levied, whereas from the levy up to June 30, 1932, there was only 4.2 per cent, de - linquent of the total tax levied. It should further be understood that this decrease was not caused by any one department or institution over - spending its appropriation, but by prevailing conditions which made it impossible for many to pay their taxes. Furthermore, the proceeds of the liquor tax, under the Act of 1935, went into the State General Fund. However, the Legislature in 1937 transferred the liquor tax from the General Fund to the State Assistance Fund. Accordingly, then, when the state levy was made in 1937, and again in 1938, the levy was increased to absorb the loss from the liquor taxes. In other words, the levy was increased from 1.76 in 1936 to 2.68 in 1938. « The demands upon the state seem to be ever increasing, and added activities in turn have caused increased state expenditures. For the biennium ended June 30, 1936, the state expenditures totaled $44,392,975.52, while for the two years ended June 30, 1938, the total was $60,277,445.67, an increase of $15,884,470.15, or about 35.7 per cent. REGISTRATION OF BONDS During this biennium the Auditor's office examined and regis - tered bonds of the various sub-divisions of the state, in the a mount of $7,258,169.79, as shown in Statement No. 8. Of the $7,258,169.79 bonds registered, only $2,734,512.32 were original bonds. The balance were refunding. All of these bonds were refunded at an interest rate considerably lower than were the original issues, which means a sub - stantial reduction in interest, or considerable savings to the taxpayers. An effort has been made by this department to accurately ascer - tain the amount of bonded indebtedness of the various subdivisions of the state. County Clerks have been requested to furnish statements of the bonded indebtedness of their county, or of the municipalities or districts, etc., within their county, in accordance with Statute 11-206. On the basis of such reports and the records of the State Auditor, Statement No. 9 — has been compiled. This shows a substan - tial reduction in the state's bonded indebtedness. Statement No. 9 shows the outstanding bonded indebtedness of the various sub-divis - ions, arranged by counties. The bonds outstanding on June 30, 1938, totaled $70,899,930.90, reflecting a decrease of indebtedness of ap - proximately $8,449,134.04. The sub-divisions are to be congratulated on the very fine showing they have made in the past two years, in re-

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS ducing the bonded indebtedness of the various municipal and rural divisions of this state. The above figures are believed to be substan - tially correct for most counties. However, some of the counties ap - pear to have kept no records during the earlier years, and the bond records of former state auditors, in some cases, are found faulty also. I hope that the authorities of the various counties, municipali - ities or districts, will scrutinize the figures shown in this report, and •notify this department of any discrepancies, so that the records may be completed or corrected. LOSS TO PERMANENT SCHOOL FUNDS In looking over the report of the Hanson Audit Company, re - garding the audit and investigation of the State Treasurer's office, it would seem that one of the greatest losses suffered by the state was that wherein "The Board of Educational Lands and Funds authorized the State Treasurer to charge off certain Permanent Fund invest - ments". This had to be done, of course, as there was no point in con - sidering them as assets any longer. The total loss to the Permanent School Fund, as a result of these charge-offs, amounted to approxi - mately $43,824.00. However, the constitution of the State of Ne - braska provides that the Permanent School Funds must not be im - paired. Therefore, the Legislature should make some provision for reimbursing the Permanent School Funds, for this loss. Reading further into the report, we note the following: "It seems to us, there - fore, that institutions as great as the Permanent Funds, and as im - portant, with investments of almost Fourteen Million Dollars, is entitled to a little more consistent handling' than it is getting and has gotten. There is too much haphazardness about it. It seems to us that the Permanent Funds should be under the management of a person experienced in bond investments, one who could look after all the phases of the State's investments from investigating and passing upon the bonds purchased, to seeing to and enforcing collec - tion of interest and principal; all, of course, to be under the direction and authority of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds". The above remarks are intended as no reflection on any member of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds, past or present, or upon any member of the office staff of the members of the above Board, as a great improvement has been shown in the records and management of the present officials, as members of this most important Board. These suggestions, therefore, are offered solely for the benefit of the Legislature, to call their attention to the facts, and to encourage the enactment of legislation in the creation of an Investment Counselor. This would not only| better the handling of these tremendous invest - ments of the state's Permanent Funds, but it would further act to protect our state treasury against loss.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS WARRANTS In view of the fact that the state business is ever increasing, so also are the number of warrants issued. During the fiscal years covered in this report, the following warrants were written: Fiscal Year Ended: Warrants Written Amount June 30, 1936 194,166 $26,832,438.67 June 30, 1938 197,510 $34,334,120.44 In looking over the above figures you can see there was an average of 705 warrants written per working day in the Auditor's office for the fiscal year ended 1938. Furthermore, when you stop to consider the fact that so many warrants are issued per day, you can readily see that although most of these vouchers are checked in the offices of the Tax Commissioner, the Auditor's office and the office of Secretary of State, yet, with such a large volume of warrants being drawn, it is a very difficult task for the above offices to carefully ex - amine and scrutinize all of these expenditures. I would therefore suggest that the Legislature establish a Legislative Comptroller, as was suggested in Legislative Bill No. 564-1937. This would not only facili - tate the work in the above offices, but it would also establish a definite safeguard and check in the expending of public funds. Furthermore, it would give the Legislature assurance that all expenditures were made entirely on the basis for which such funds were originally appropriated. COUNTY TREASURER EXAMINATIONS Sec. 26-1309, Comp. Statutes Nebr. 1929, as amended by Legis - lative Bill No. 310-1937, provides that an examination of the books, accounts and affairs of all county officers in every county in the state, shall be made, by the direction and under the supervision of the Auditor of Public Accounts, at least every two years. A complete and comprehensive audit of the books, accounts, records and affairs of the county treasurer and county clerk in each county, shall be made by the direction and under the supervision of the Auditor of Public Accounts". The law provides for the appointment of eight account - ants to handle this work. It also provides for the establishing of a uniform system of accounting. UNIFORM ACCOUNTING A manual of uniform accounting procedure, containing detailed instructions, was sent to every county official in the State of Nebraska during the month of September, 1937. The object, outside of com - plying with ths law, which requires the State Auditor to establish

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS uniformity, is to be helpful to county officers, to facilitate the -work of the state examiners, and to make manipulations less difficult. Also, there will be a saving to the taxpayers, since the use of standard forms, to be procured from blank book houses, will avoid the expense of having costly books ruled and printed. Such a^system of auditing and accounting would bring to the legislative body, when it meets biennially, definite information on which to base its deliberations in the matters of regulation and legislation as jit pertains to the various political sub-divisions. It would also do away with the endless controversies regarding the costs and management of our county government. Since the enactment of Legislative Bill No. J310, the Auditor's office has been able to make annual audits of every county clerk and county treasurer in the State of Nebraska. "We have also audited many of the other offices, and installed uniform forms, which from time to time should be supplemented and improved, until such a time as all county offices will be operated on a uniform basis. ■ ■ ■ ■ ■ . - ■ COUNTY BUDGET ACT OF 1937 Under Legislative Bill No. 245, the first Unicameral Legislature created the "County Budget Act of 1937". This Act applies to all counties of the state and provided that the county officials shall pre - sent a complete financial plan for each year. This plan shall set forth all proposed expenditures from funds appropriated for the administra - tion, operation and maintenance of all offices, departments, activities and institutions of the county; it shall also indicate the actual or es - timated operating deficits from prior years; it shall take account of interest and debt redemption charges during the current year; and it shall approximate the expenditures needed for capital projects to be undertaken or executed during the current year. In addition, the budget shall set forth the \ anticipated income, including all fees, li - cense taxes, taxes to be levied and all other means of financing the proposed expenditures for the current year, including any unexpended balances for delinquent taxes from prior years. Through the assistance and co-operation of the State Auditor's office, this budget act was put into effect, and although there were some technical difficulties, such as the fiscal year, nevertheless, we feel that the Uniform Accounting Law and County Budgeting Act of 1937" were, without doubt, the two most progressive pieces of legis - lation enacted during this, the first session of the Unicameral Legisla - ture,

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS SEMI-ANNUAt. AUDITS OF STATE TREASURER At the recommendation of the Governor, the Legislature appro - priated $2,000.00 for semi-annual audits of the State Treasurer. believe this to be a most forward step in the protoction of the public treasury; for these semi-annual audits, made (by certified public ac - countants), under the direction of the State Auditor, will, in time, tend to establish very definite checks and limitations in the adminis - tration of public monies. AUDITING OF STATE OFFICES During the past biennium this office has conducted audits an - nually in all of our State Normal Schools. We have also made audits of the State Liquor Commission, the State Land Commissioner's office, the Department of Agriculture and Inspection, the Clerk of the Su - preme Court, the office of the Secretary of State, the State Boxing Commissioner, the Fish and Game Commission, the Metropolitan Util - ities District, the State Fund Relief Committee of the American Le - gion, the Nebraska State Racing Commission and the State Historical Society. Through these audits we have tried not to be too critical, but rather to recommend and suggest such changes in the accounting systems as would admit of more modern and uniform accounting methods and better business practices. IN CONCLUSION Now that I come to the end of my term as State Auditor, I want to express my sincere appreciation of the confidence shown in me by the people of the State. It has been a great privilege and honor to represent the people in so important an office as that of State Auditor of Public Accounts. I have enjoyed the friendship and good will of the various state officers and employees, and I am retiring with the belief that the work of my department has been satisfactory. Great credit is- due the personnel of the Auditor's office who have assisted me in keeping up the records of the State, and having them at all times ready for public inspection. Respectfully submitted WILLIAM H. PRICE State Auditor of Public Accounts State of Nebraska

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Governor's office, July 28, 1938. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment met at the Governor's office at 11 o'clock A. M., Thursday, July 28, 1938, with the following members present: Governor, R. L. Cochran, State Auditor W. H. Price, and State Tax Commissioner Wm. H. Smith. Absent: Secretary of State Harry R. Swanson and State Treas - urer Walter H. Jensen. The Tax Commissioner presented the following basis for the 1938 state tax fund levy: BASIS FOR THE 1938 STATE TAX LEVY The report of the State Auditor shows the appro - priations from the state general fund for the biennial period of 1937-9 to be $12,373,837.99 One-half of which was met from the 1937 levy, leaving to be raised in 1938, the sum of 6,186,919.00 The estimated revenue from the intang - ible tax is $100,963.00 Plus miscellaneous receipts as per audi - tor's report 804,843.38 905,806.38 which leaves to be raised from the general fund levy 5,281,112.62 which amount is increased 3 per cent in accordance with the provisions of Section 77-1007 of the Com - piled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929 . $ 158,433.38 Making the total -to be raised from the 1938 general fund levy 5,439,546.00 The valuation of the state has been found to be $2,033,302,482., applied to which a levy of 2.68 mills on the dollar will raise the sum of $ 5,449,250.65 Accordingly, the general fund' levy for 1938 is hereby fixed at 2.68 mills by the State Board of Equal - ization and Assessment this 28th day of July, 1938. The miscellaneous collections for the general fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1938, were reported by State Auditor Price, as follows: GENERAL FUND RECEIPTS — MISCELLANEOUS July 1, 1937 to June 30, 1938. Supreme Court $ 8,519.87 Governor 47.50 Secretary of State 154,962.65 Estate Taxes Land Commissioner 3,383.50 Car Line Taxes . ~_ 44,341.55 Roads and Irrigation 272.31 State Library (Sale of Books/ 1,879.91

i REPORT OF AUDITOR OP PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Income from current cash 2,383.28 Insurance Tax 586,942.16 Suspense Acc't. (Failed Banks) 64.96 Bank Charges & Fees 25.00 Miscellaneous Refunds 381.70 Compensation Court - 634.70 Auditor 109.93 Tax Commissioner 15.00 Banking Department 879.36 > $804,843.38 ■ The Tax Commissioner moved the approval of the basis for the levy, the motion being seconded by Auditor Price, and carried -I unanimously. .'■■■" i i There being no further business to come before the Board, it j adjourned subject to call. i (Signed) Wm. H. Smith, State Tax Commissioner and Secretary of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. .
